headline: Tofu Parmigiana
description: Breaded tofu a la parmigiana. You'll just about swear this is eggplant or veal! One of my husband's favorites, and he doesn't even suspect! Serve with a simple crisp green salad, angel hair pasta and garlic bread.
name: Tofu Parmigiana

recipeInstructions.text: In a small bowl, combine bread crumbs, 2 tablespoons Parmesan cheese, 1 teaspoon oregano, salt, and black pepper.
Slice tofu into 1/4 inch thick slices, and place in bowl of cold water. One at a time, press tofu slices into crumb mixture, turning to coat all sides.
Heat oil in a medium skillet over medium heat. Cook tofu slices until crisp on one side. Drizzle with a bit more olive oil, turn, and brown on the other side.

Combine tomato sauce, basil, garlic, and remaining oregano. Place a thin layer of sauce in an 8 inch square baking pan. Arrange tofu slices in the pan. Spoon remaining sauce over tofu. Top with shredded mozzarella and remaining 3 tablespoons Parmesan.
Bake at 400 degrees F (205 degrees C) for 20 minutes.

review.reviewBody: This came out so good! I also sliced and froze the tofu. It made it much easier to handle and gave it more of a "meatier" texture. I baked it with a little olive oil drizzled on each side for 20 min at 400 degrees. Then I put it together with the sauce and cheese and reheated it!

Love this recipe! My grandchildren cannot get enough. I cut the tofu into the 1/4 inch slices the recipe calls for and press the extra water out. Then I dip the tofu pieces in beaten eggs and into the breadcrumb mixture. I sprinkle the tofu with a little olive oil, spray Pam on an aluminum lined baking sheet and cook at 400 degrees for 20 minutes, turning halfway thru. Then I proceed with the recipe as called for. Baking the tofu is much easier that frying it in a pan. Easy peasy and loved by all!

here are the changes I made I used arrabbiata sauce so no need to add garlic basil and rosemary I sliced tofu wrapped them in paper towels to take water out. then put it in freezer for 30 mins after that i dipped them in egg then breadcrumbs then fried them in oil. then arranged in a 8x8 with sause tofu cheese and repeat. baked for 20 mins on 400
I dipped the tofu into egg which added to the taste and helped the bread crumb mixture stay on the tofu pieces.
Love this! I dipped the tofu in egg instead of water, which I'd recommend. I also used quite a bit more of an Italian blend of grated cheeses. My teen and husband loved it.

If you are looking for a meatless Monday or every day meal try this great recipe! I have made it many times and it's always delicious! I always dredge with flour, followed by egg, then into gf bread crumbs or gf crackers for the coating and I also bake it. Read the reviews for extra tips and oven temp. Enjoy!
I made it renal friendly and used a red bell pepper sauce. It was good.
This was real delicious. I made it in my air fryer. Wonderful.
nice
awesome parmigiana
I love this page
not bad
I was surprised how gone this turned out. It was my first try at cookim

Delicious. I did dredge the sliced tofu in flour and then egg before I coated with the breadcrumbs, it worked perfectly. I used my tofu press instead of freezing it, it is much faster and worked really well.

Very surprised how well this dish came out. I had a bit of a time getting the bread crumbs to stick to the tofu, but I'm a cooking noob. First time cooking tofu, in fact. My wife and I both loved the dish. It did taste very much like eggplant parmigian.
Fabulous! Next time doubling the recipe for more leftovers.
Added image
So yummy! Did the flour-egg-bread crumb-baking method. Fried up nicely and was so tasty and the texture great! Used a LOT of garlic powder, sage and oregano in the breading as well.
8/31/20 Next time, cook the garlic first, bake the tofu first and maybe skip the breading all together (carbs and sticking issue).
I made a diet version and omitted the oil and breadcrumbs and it was delicious. The spices are wonderful and make the dish

This is so delicious, and a go-to dish for entertaining family with celiac (using gluten-free bread crumbs) and vegetarian dietary constraints. Bonus: EVERYONE - even those without dietary restrictions - loves it!

This recipe is delicious, but as with many tofu recipes it falls very short of what is required to get your tofu to really perform. Here are my steps to getting tofu to really seem like chicken:

- Freeze it then use it. The resulting texture change is great.
- You want to get the moisture out of the tofu not add it in. If the tofu is a little dry it will absorb the liquids (and their flavours). To accomplish this press the block of tofu between too flat surfaces to squeeze out as much moisture as you can. Be careful not to press too hard or you'll crush it. Next lay the slices out on a lightly oiled sheet and put them on broil (10-15 min a side). (I love my toaster oven for this). They will get a slight gold colour and become a just a little crunchy. Don't worry the crunchiness goes away when it re-absorbs moisture.

I’m giving this recipe five stars. I love using tofu instead of eggplant like I normally do. The tofu took a while frying on each side To get to a golden color because I try to minimize a lot of oil...even olive oil. My husband absolutely loved it.
slice smaller strips to make it more crispy

We loved this! It does take a bit of time to coat the tofu and then fry it and then bake it, but with the tomato sauce and cheese, it tastes very much like lasagna. Will definitely make it again - soon!
Simple, yet delicious, recipe. I did not fry the tofu, but only baked it instead. It was still delicious and those I shared it with agreed.
Loved it!
Amazing
I did it wrong but I still liked it.
Awesome!
So good!
reviews count
I made this recipe and really liked it. Thank you for your creative use of tofu.

I followed the recipe very closely. The only changes I made were to add crimini mushrooms because I needed to use them before they spoiled, to substitute Trader Joe's Arrabiata sauce for the tomato sauce, and to substitute Spice and Tea Exchange Italian Street Fair herb mix for the oregano. Served over garlic and herb miracle noodles. Will definitely fix again!

Both kids loved this - I was shocked because they say they don’t like tofu..... they gobbled it up. “Tastes like something from a restaurant!” I used prepared marinara rather than bothering with the tomato sauce and other ingredients since I was in a hurry. Also didn’t have Italian breadcrumbs on hand so I toasted some bread, grated it, and threw in Italian seasoning. I did dip the tofu in egg prior to coating as was recommended here. This will be a staple in our newly vegetarian household...
This is amazing! Even my 4 and 6 year old, with no experience with tofu, loved it.
tester
tes
used the flour, egg, seasoned bread crumbs and baking method mentioned in other reviews. It was amazing.

My first experience with tofu was terrible. This had to do with how I cooked the tofu. After making the Tofu Lasagna I am now a lover of Tofu. I will be searching for more Tofu recipes. The recipe was easy with basic ingredients I had already. The Tofu Lasagna was delicious.
This is a great recipe, love it so much

I almost followed the recipe. I also used the suggestion to bake the slices of tofu before breading and frying. The texture was fantastic. Also, I used the standard breading (flour, egg, bread crumbs (+parmesan). Definitely one of my favorites.

My wife and I are just starting to experiment with meatless cooking (meat is getting too darned expensive!), and since we both love Italian food I thought I'd give this recipe a try. Unfortunately, I had bought medium firm tofu instead of extra firm, so the slices were a pain to handle (turn while frying, transferring to the baking dish, serving, etc.). Also, while the sauce and cheese was tasty the tofu was rather bland so next time I think I'll marinate the tofu overnight in a chicken broth or something like that to give it a bit more flavor. Not withstanding the above criticisms, the dish turned out really well, so we enjoyed it. Thanks so much for sharing!
had a hard time getting the bread crumbs to stick!

I first found this recipe years ago when my daughter in middle school was having a sleepover and she had friends that didn't eat meat. The girls all really liked it. Now in my 50's I have revisited it. (trying to be more healthy in my older age LOL) "fried" my breaded tofu in the air fryer for 10 minutes and used low fat provolone for the cheese. I did press my tofu as I always do, and tossed it in the freezer for about an hour. Super good!!!
Love it. Picture in my photo area. To small to put it here.

Very easy and very delicious recipe. My family really enjoyed it and asked me to make it again even though they're not as fond of tofu as I am. I did change the recipe slightly and used egg to attach the breading to the tofu strips because attaching the breading with only the water didn't work when frying, so I gave up on the frying, re-breaded the tofu and threw it in the oven and it still turned out delicious.
The only thing I would say, cut the tofu into exactly 8 pieces so it fits in the 8x8 pan.

Instead of just soaking the tofu in water and applying breadcrumbs, I dried the tofu as much as possible, and then did the flour egg breadcrumb situation that you would see with most chicken parm recipes. The result was really good! A little soggy, but that's to be expected with the bake time.

My husband and I enjoyed this recipe enough that we'll be making it again. I tried to stick to the original recipe, but I only had an 8x6 pan, so the 14 slices of tofu I ended up with had to be arranged in two layers, which meant that I had to use more sauce, herbs, and cheese. In essence, I only increased the amount of some of the ingredients. I don't see a need to change anything, unless you want a medium-firm tofu for a slightly creamier texture. If I have shaved Parmesan on hand next time, I'll try that over the grated Parmesan. I would recommend this recipe to others.
So yummy! Instead of using bread crumbs I used crushed up oat bran cereal and it was so hearty and it really made the tofu crisp up nicely!

As other people suggested I froze the sliced tofu for 30 min. I used the flour, egg and panko breading. I sprayed the breaded tofu with Pam and baked it at 350 degrees for 30 min., turning once after 15 min. I used homemade tomato sauce that I had in the fridge. Very tasty!
This was great! I pressed my tofu for a bit to remove extra water before dipping in egg and then continuing with the recipe as written. My house of carnivores loved this.

Whoever created this needs to work on their measurements. 1. No way will 12 oz of firm tofu, cut into 1/4 inch slices, fit into an 8"x8" pan. Not in this universe. 2. All the breadcrumbs slide off during frying. How much force did you use to make it stick?! 3. Tasted okay but nothing special. Won't waste my tofu on this again
Delicious way to eat tofu! Thanks for the tips. Dipped in flour/egg/bread crumbs. Baked in the oven instead of using frying pan.
It was just okay. Maybe less so, really 2.5 stars, if it were available. Plated with salad, serves 3-4.
Excellent.Loved it
Was delicious! Our 5 year old loved it! Used Mid’s 4 cheese tomato sauce — it was yummy!
Extremely easy to make. You are in control of the flavor. I made my sauce spicy. And added a little extra seasoning to the breadcrumbs.

Made this for dinner tonight, the eve of Thanksgiving. I selected the recipe because tofu is always a good low-calorie, high protein alternative! I used one reviewer's suggestion to bake the tofu prior to coating it and frying it. I was skeptical as I thought it might make the tofu rubbery. But it was a very smart step to use as the tofu was mosdef firmer. Overall the dish was delicious. While I couldn't fool my husband into thinking the tofu was anything else, he actually commented on how much meatier it was, more like a portobello in texture. Will use this recipe again. I'd've rated it 4.5 but couldn't figure out how to do that!
Tofu with a great parmigiana treatment.

Very good!!! I followed others recommendations to slice, dry, freeze. As well as dip in flour, egg, then crumbs(I used panko). I also baked rather than fried. 
I used my own marinara sauce, which I use for everything!

It had a wonderful flavor and texture! My husband said he likes it better than chicken parm!!! Who knew :-D

I wasn't as blown away by this recipe as many others have been. I thought it had a fair amount of prep work because of the multi-faceted tofu prep before actual baking time began. Also, I didn't think the final result was as splendid as most did. It was certainly edible, but I can't see me making it again.
I changed and used pasta sauce instead of tomato sauce. I will definitely make this again! Yum.
The breading didn't work at all! It didn't stick at all because the recipe has no eggs or milk.
First time eating Tofu. I was pleasantly surprised. I will be making this again.

Phenomenal. I used strained tomatoes (essentially the same as tomato sauce) and even got my carnivorous sister to try it and she loves it, and always asks me to make it again. I absolutely loved it. 

For vegetarian but non-vegan option to make the breadcrumbs stick better when frying use an egg wash.
Great recipe! I just made some for dinner and it was just GONE in a matter of minutes! I did follow others' suggestions of using an egg wash instead of just water. I will absolutely make this again.

I loved this recipe, and I've had only a modicum of success with Tofu. We didn't have anything in the house to eat, so... my hubby who's an avowed meat eater, even loved this. 

I did change it in small ways, in that I didn't use parmagna because it gives me migraines. I substituted Romano and it was delish. I also added an egg so that the bread crumbs would stick to the tofu, because I drained it too well. Probably my own fault. I'll try it again and see.

No changes, served with a side of mostaccioli and tossed green salad. I made on served on Fathers Day, I'm the Dad! My daughter (who is a budding vegetarian) took the leftovers home, a good sign.
Next time, will double the sauce recipe to cover the pasta too.
also will make the slices thicker, which will require more tofu.
Quick, simple and very tasty by itself or over pasta!
We thought it was great. we added both oregano and basil. we will make it again for sure. We used extra firm tofu, it happened to be organic.
The only change I made is I used egg for the wash instead of water. It was extremely tasty-I'll definitely make it again!
I used extra firm tofu and was happy with the texture. I did not make the sauce as in the recipe, but used a jar of pre-made pasta sauce.

Half of my family is vegetarian and half is not. This is a great basic recipe to make both ways. I double the recipe and use half of the bread coating for the tofu and half for chicken. If you work with the tofu first, you'll be able to use only one fry pan. However, most vegetarians would prefer you bake the tofu and chicken in separate pans. The only change I've made is that I press the water out of the tofu and dip the slices in a beaten egg to before coating it with the bread crumbs. After the tofu is in the pan and ready for the oven, I repeat the process with two chicken breasts (cut in two thinner slices each). Both can go in the oven at the same time. Adding pasta marinara on the side makes this a meal the entire family can eat without TWICE the work of two separate meals. Thanks for a great recipe.
So delicious. I doubled the sauce and it turned out great! Thanks for sharing this yummy recipe!

This dish was delicious although I did make a few changes (and a great unusual way to cook tofu) .

Based on another review, I decided to bake the "breaded" tofu rather than frying it. I dipped the tofu slices in whole wheat flour, then egg, then almond meal prior to baking them for 15 min per side at 350 degrees (olive oil on cookie sheet). 

After baking, I layered sauce (jarred red sauce), tofu then shredded mozzarella cheese (very minimal amount) repeating the layers a second time and topping with parmesan cheese.

This dish was excellent even as leftovers - thank you for sharing the recipe!!!
Yummy!
Didn't make any changes. Won't make it again. I didn't care for the recipe.

Easy and good. I don't fry, only bake. Dip 1/4 inch tofu slices in egg, then crumbs (no flour). Also used jarred spaghetti sauce so that made it easier, didn't have to bother adding the garlic etc to the sauce. Also, I did freeze the tofu slices for 30 mins.

It's a wonderful substitute for chicken parm, as written. I drained, pressed, froze and defrosted my tofu first (already sliced of course). Made my owned specially seasoned bread crumbs and it fried up beautifully. Used seasoned diced tomatoes in place of just sauce and topped with a generous amount of mozzarella and Parmesan. I agree with the others - best tofu recipe yet!
Used fresh basil and twice the garlic.

This dish is delicious! Great flavor and easy to make. I have a 19 month old so I did all the prep work during his afternoon nap. I substituted panko for seasoned breadcrumbs and seasoned the panko with salt, pepper, and Herbs de Provence.

Other than using my own red sauce, I followed this recipe. It was great! I'm not a huge tofu lover, but I was making chicken parm for a dinner party and one guest is a vegetarian. She loved this, too!

Use the egg to dip the tofu, as noted in other reviews, DON"T soak the Tofu in water, user a colander to drain excess water before cutting ii into desired width and coating in bread crumbs. You will get a better result. VERY delicious but it won't as for eggplant :;
First time really cooking with tofu, we could still tell what it was but it tasted very good regardless.

Love love love this. Fairly new to tofu (this was only the 2nd time I've used it) so was grateful for the tips from the other reviewers. I froze slices for 30 min, then used cooking spray to help the breading stick. I went the baking route rather than frying, and the texture was just amazing. Love the cheeses on it, but will probably up the sauce amount a bit next time. Absolutely fantastic recipe; would never know this was tofu!

We used a tofu press, and pressed tofu overnight. We got 16, 1/4" thick slices. As a result we used a 9x13" pan. We also used ready made pasta sauce instead of tomato sauce and the spices. The tofu came out great, very "meat" like texture. Will definitely make it again.
I baked it first as recommended and it turned out wonderfully!
this is amazing everyone in my family loves it
followed the recipe i thought it was very good it took awhile to make will plan ahead next time i would make it again!
Easy to make; thought it was delicious. Thanks!

I just want to say I absolutely loved this and will be doing it again soon. Thank you for this clever idea! I mixed the breaded mixture in my sauce and poured it on the tofu that way before sprinkling the shredded cheese on top. Yummmm ?? *notice 2 were gone before I was able to take a picture haha

freeze tofu for 30 mins before. slice. dip in flour, egg, and panko seasoned with salt, pepper, parsley, and oregano. bake at 375 for 25 mins, turning halfway through. use one jar trader joe's tomato basil pasta sauce & one can tomato sauce for a doubled recipe. sprinkle fresh parsley on top before baking.
Loved this recipe, nice to find a different way to make tofu!

I made changes in order to veganize this recipe but overall it's a good recipe. After draining the water from the tofu (it's a must), I marinated the sliced tofu in olive oil, balsamic vinegar, basil & oregano (for 20 mins), breaded than baked for 20 mins at 350. I cut up Chao Cheese (coconut tofu based cheese) to melt over the baked tofu. Sauce was tasty. Thanks for sharing.
Fantastic stuff!! didn't change a thing, served with spaghetti. It's a new classic---thank you!

This is really good. I added cumin and parsley and used a 15 oz can of tomato sauce (I love sauce). I gave it only four stars because of the lack of crispiness. I'll probably use the flour-and-egg mixture along with the crumbs next time.
Very good
